chapter.title: AJF - Web and User interface
chapter.para: The AJF Web module provides a common interface and design model to create a dynamic web site in order to interact with end users. The user interface will use standard services offered and exposed by the Business Layer.

section.title: Internationalization
section.para: Internationalization mechanism allows your application to be able to manage languages of your different end users. It used configuration of the web browser to know which language apply and choose translation defined in some property files. These files are stored in the folder /src/main/resources/i18n in your web module. we define for example two files, messages.properties and messages_FR.properties that will contains keys and translations.
section.section:
Global configurationThe main configuration is stored in the WEB-INF/faces-config.xml. This configuration is the same for all AJF project and shouldn't be modified if not mandatory. <?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?> <faces-config xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee/web-facesconfig_2_0.xsd" version="2.0"> <application> <message-bundle>i18n.messages</message-bundle>
<locale-config> <default-locale>en</default-locale> <supported-locale>fr</supported-locale> <supported-locale>en</supported-locale> </locale-config> <resource-bundle> <base-name>i18n.messages</base-name> <var>m</var> </resource-bundle> </application> </faces-config>
. Depending of the configuration of the Web Brower, the Application Server will use one or the other configuration. If the key doesn't exist, you will see something like ???the.key???. if the key doesn't exist on the language used in the web browser of the end user, he will use the default language configured in the application ('en' by default). In the first one (src/main/resources/i18n/messages.properties), button.submit=Submit In the second one (src/main/resources/i18n/messages_FR.properties); button.submit=Soumettre
Using key in the JSF page
I18N can be use in every label or JSF component directly. , in the JSP
<p:commandButton value="#{m['button.submit']}" .../>
For key without using ".", we can use direct pointed notation #{m.toto} instead of using the array notation. It doesn't work with complex key. the key 'toto.txt' doesn't allow to use #{m.toto} but we will use #{m['toto.txt']

section.title: Using key in a backing bean
section.para: AJF offered some method to get a translation directly in java using class WebUtils.getLabel()

section.title: Templating
section.para: AJF propose a standard layout named "WEB-INF/templates/simpleLayout.xhtml" that you can use in order to organize your page. This layout is divide in three parts:

listitem.para: The "header" that will contains ArcelorMittal logo, title of the application, menu, login/logout mechanism, Technical stuff , HelpAbout part.
The "content" part that you will use to add your components

section.programlisting: AJF2 Showcase
section.para: By default, the SimpleLayout.xhtml template will load menu and title which will be defined ion src/main/webapp/shared folder.
You also have the possibility for each page to overload the applicationTitle which will be used as title of the brower window. By default, the i18n key application.title will be displayed.

section.title: Template customization
section.para: You can add you own css class style in src/main/webapp/resources/css/custom.css

section.title: Template creation
section.para: If needed, put your own templates in src/main/webapp/shared/templates folder. We will not explain in his document how to do it, but you can pick an eye on the SimpleLayout.xhtml in WEB-INF/template folder.
